At 00:11 25/03/2004 +0000, you wrote:
>Ian, this is definitely an interesting topic.

Since my interest already leant in the direction of:
1) how to form a system form multiple evolving components
2) how to structure that system for maximum evolvability
I found Hayek very interesting.  It has a couple of holes in it, but I 
wouldn't want _all_ the good work to be already done :)

>   In the Hayek system, is
>there a difference between training and testing?  The way you
>described it, it sounds like it i always training, so there is always
>a chance of a mutant making a bid.

There's no probability in the decision to make a bid, it's a deterministic 
outcome of the individuals response to its input.  The authors report on 
systems using the bids to form a probability distribution with poor results.

In the examples that they've documented bidding mostly (if not always) 
takes the form of a yes/no decision whether to make a fixed bid.  The bid 
size is a simple mutatable property of the individual.  The decision 
whether to bid or not tends to be from quite simple forms of pattern matching.

Neither the fixed bid, nor the pattern matching is part of the basic 
concept, however.  I think they were just simple approaches taken because 
they suited the problems studied.  I have been assuming that when I get 
around to try a similar approach, I will treat the bid as a general output 
from the individual (I'm starting with GP, but ultimately I plan to support 
GP and ANN individuals in the same system, so this output might be derived 
internally in a few different ways).

Since learning only occurs via the creation and destruction of individuals, 
training can be halted merely by suppressing these activities.  Bids would 
still act to select the next active individual, but there would be no need 
to actually transfer the funds (although if you did, it might form useful 
performance tracking data).

>   Or does the probability go down
>for some reason?  I guess I should go read the paper...

They're not too long and easy to read....

         Ian Badcoe
